repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body: This PR is introducing pure python mode in Profiling tutorial. It is partial fix of #4187

comment_data.body: we need to import cython because of this line
and add empty lines to pyx version, of course

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,11 @@
+# cython: profile=True
+
+def recip_square(i: cython.int):
+    return 1. / i ** 2
+
+def approx_pi(n: cython.int=10000000):

comment_data.body: we need to import cython because of this line

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,16 @@
+# cython: profile=True
+
+@cython.cfunc
+@cython.inline
+@cython.exceptval(-1.0)
+def recip_square(i: int) -> cython.double:
+    return 1. / (i * i)
+
+def approx_pi(n: cython.int=10000000):

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
def recip_square(i: cython.int) -> float:
```
we can use `float` here i think it will look better
but `int` must be with `cython`

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,16 @@
+# cython: profile=True
+
+@cython.cfunc
+@cython.inline
+@cython.exceptval(-1.0)
+def recip_square(i: int) -> cython.double:
+    return 1. / (i * i)
+
+def approx_pi(n: cython.int=10000000):
+    val: cython.double = 0.
+    k: cython.int
+    for k in range(1, n + 1):
+        val += recip_square(k)
+    return (6 * val) ** .5
+
+

@@ -0,0 +1,17 @@
+# cython: profile=True
+
+import cython
+
+@cython.profile(False)
+@cython.cfunc
+@cython.inline
+@cython.exceptval(-1.0)
+def recip_square(i: cython.int) -> cython.double:
+    return 1. / (i * i)
+
+def approx_pi(n: cython.int=10000000):

@@ -0,0 +1,11 @@
+# cython: profile=True
+
+def recip_square(i: cython.int):
+    return 1. / i ** 2
+
+def approx_pi(n: cython.int=10000000):
+    val: cython.double = 0.

@@ -0,0 +1,16 @@
+# cython: profile=True
+
+@cython.cfunc
+@cython.inline
+@cython.exceptval(-1.0)
+def recip_square(i: int) -> cython.double:
+    return 1. / (i * i)
+
+def approx_pi(n: cython.int=10000000):
+    val: cython.double = 0.

@@ -0,0 +1,17 @@
+# cython: profile=True
+
+import cython
+
+@cython.profile(False)
+@cython.cfunc
+@cython.inline
+@cython.exceptval(-1.0)
+def recip_square(i: cython.int) -> cython.double:

@@ -0,0 +1,17 @@
+# cython: profile=True
+
+import cython
+
+@cython.profile(False)
+@cython.cfunc
+@cython.inline
+@cython.exceptval(-1.0)
+def recip_square(i: cython.int) -> cython.double:
+    return 1. / (i * i)
+
+def approx_pi(n: cython.int=10000000):
+    val: cython.double = 0.

comment_data.body: To be honest, I prefer to have explicit `cython.double` here. Cython is automatically using `double` C type when variable is annotated by python `float` type. This can be confusing for the newcomers. I agree that it would look better but in tutorial I prefer to not introduce this hidden complexity.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,16 @@
+# cython: profile=True
+
+@cython.cfunc
+@cython.inline
+@cython.exceptval(-1.0)
+def recip_square(i: int) -> cython.double:
+    return 1. / (i * i)
+
+def approx_pi(n: cython.int=10000000):
+    val: cython.double = 0.
+    k: cython.int
+    for k in range(1, n + 1):
+        val += recip_square(k)
+    return (6 * val) ** .5
+
+

comment_data.body:
It has already been used in docs in new pythonized versions, so you are not introducing anything here.

But look at it like this: you are seeing cython for the first time and you dont know that behind the scenes python `float` is actually `double`, and this is where you get even more confused, for pythonista it is easier to use the already known `float`.
And there is no hiding here, it is nicely described [here](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/pure.html#pep-484-type-annotations)
